turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: You can go by mule and wagon.
The State of Tennessee in their brief and in their argument here has taken Arkansas to task because of its pleadings in this particular case.
When we did draft our pleadings, we did allege that there was no avulsion.

This was based on testimony and this was based on what we felt was the case but whenever our engineer got in to it, we found out that we could not take the position that there had not been some sort of an avulsion here.
They say that Smith, our expert changed his testimony, I think that I can explain to the Court why his testimony was changed.

Whenever he first started testifying concerning this in private litigation, he took the position that there had been no avulsion and the reason why he did this was that at that time alone in this particular area had not become definite or crystallized and was not certain.

Smith took the position around 15 years ago that this -- what they call a middle bar or mud bar that became this part would -- did not have any vegetation on it and that low water was the only time that it came up as sand and mud, he took the position and the law was not clear that that changes on each side of that particular thing would not be an avulsion or would not move the thalweg or the river but a case from the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals which was certiorari was denied up here and which is 211 Uhlhorn versus US Gypsum Company 366 F.2d. 211 certiorari denied here 385 US 1026 said that yes whenever the avultive part was you could see it at low water that changes on each side of that would result in an avulsion, that is the reason why his testimony was changed from the time we plead and at the time of the trial.

And we do not think that his position is inconsistent, he was just instructed to take this case into consideration by our attorneys -- by the state's attorneys whenever he formed his report and he had to follow the Yula Horn decision and saying yes there was an avulsion but he did say that he wasn't sure that there really was but he was going to give the State of Tennessee the benefit of the doubt and say, “Yes there was a small avulsion still remain there due to the master's and Pilot's report of the middle bar or a mud bar.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How much tax does Arkansas get out of this profit?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, I do not know.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is it getting any?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I think severance taxes maybe all for timber and few things like that but I don't think that taxes would be very much.
But it has so list as the record reflects has sold these lands for taxes over there in Arkansas.
That's how the Arkansas -- the land has sold in Arkansas.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That Island?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, it has sold tax that has been forfeited for taxes and it forfeits to the state and then the state to its land Commissioner gives tax deeds so it has derived some revenue from it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How much should you pay for it?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I don't know Your Honor.
I'm advised that someone asked that there was -- how much forming land there was on, there's approximately 500 acres that can be farmed there now.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Out of 5,000?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Out of 5,000 most of this timber land.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But a farmer keep his home and just place the mules tooled and everything over in Arkansas and farmer won't let out?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
That's what they're doing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what they are doing?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's what our citizens are doing.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, is there any evidence in the record that the farmers are doing that?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There is?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: We have formed that all along our citizens have.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that's in the record?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I suppose it's not uncommon on land boundaries for the farmers to have the farm –they have got couple of hundred acres in one state and spill over into the next state.
Nothing unique about that is there?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I wouldn't think so, of course here the river would make it too feasible but you could own some on both sides.
I think Mr. Sutton in his -- when he was being questioned by Mr. Justice White clearly shows the Arkansas position is the one that should be accepted by this Court.

The prior case of Arkansas versus Tennessee says that when the strange stagnates and ceases to flow and it smells bad and that's when the land is set that any accretions or any erosion or accretion is a natural result of that avulsion.
Mr. Sutton wants these accretions and erosions to keep moving this line even though it's not the channel anymore.
He wants that the case of Tennessee versus Arkansas says that these erosions and accretions are -- and sedimentations is a natural result of the dying of the old thalweg.

That's why this Court has to decide when and where the old thalweg died because if it keeps eroding and keeps accreting, it's really not dead and it keeps moving and its fluid which is what this Court does in its prior decision seems to say it does want to do, it wants to have the old dead thalweg inactive and then let the new one control the lands.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well I gather that Tennessee concedes that the old channel died some years ago and it is now dead, the boundary won't change anymore.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: He still says it's a -- he says -- but the accretions that attached to it and the erosions that are attached to it will move the state line if he says -- his position is that it has done it though --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, not up to the north and west relief into that territory and it doesn't seem to me that even if you have some difference about what to test or to be when the old channel dies if you both agree that that state line in 1912 was where that maps showed it was?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: We don't agree where it was Your Honor.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's right.
He claim -- the State of Tennessee claims that these accretions and erosions have moved -- we claim it's in, what they term is Smith scar.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well if the state line is where he says that was in 1912 to the north and the west, Cow Island or that segment of Cow Island, the state line is where he said it was all the accretions and where on the Tennessee side of that line.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's not our position Your Honor.
Our position is that the accretions built down from the Arkansas shore and attached to this evolved there.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yeah, well that's your second point?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's your second?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Isn't it?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Not your first one?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well how about the first one?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: We claim that the thalweg died at around 1918 in that particular point and it could not move any further.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let's assume you're right on that, what's the consequence of that?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Any movement of it would --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, there wouldn't be anymore movement in your position?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And I didn't know that he indicates that the west and the north of that island that he doesn't claim that the state line changed any --

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor it's our position that this evolved area keep eroding away and got to where Smith scar was whenever the thalweg died.
The important thing here, we think the Court to decide is when and where this thalweg died set the boundary line there in a definite place and a portion of these lands and accordance there with.
We either ask the Court to reverse the fact that reversed the conclusions of the Master and inner findings and inconsistency with our position or to send that matter back for further proceedings.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything in the record that shows why Arkansas filed this suit?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, we filed this lawsuit on the basis of request from officials of Crittenden County who were prevailed upon by the private citizens who were involved there.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is that shown in the record?

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I think it is Your Honor and the county officials prevailed upon the Governor to request the Attorney General to file the lawsuit.
It originates from these private persons who were involved in litigation Tennessee the private Arkansas persons who claim the land.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Langston I was about to ask you a question which has nothing to do with the merits of the case but perhaps you could answer if you know.

Is there any jurisdictional constitutional reason why your states, State of Arkansas could not agree with another state, State of Tennessee for example, by legislative action to submit this kind of dispute to a joint commission established by the two states, would you be legally permitted to do or maybe a large legal question that if you know I'm interested in your answer.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: We have took the position that the Tennessee litigation which decided the issue in favor of the Tennessee people would preclude our Arkansas residents of filing anything in the State Court of Arkansas.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I didn't mean in Courts, I mean the joint commissions established by two -- the legislatures of two contending states with an agreement just submitted to final and binding arbitration instead of bringing it under the constitutional provisions here.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: Your Honor, I don't know but since we've been losing this case we're probably happy to do that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That be perhaps a compact that would have to be approved by counsel, any such interstate agreement.
Not that there would probably be any problem for getting congressional proof.

turn.speaker: don_langston
turn.label: Mr. Don Langston
turn.text: I suppose it would Your Honor, I really don't know.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: This has been done on the -- by state water commission but that's in New York, New Jersey but that perhaps have little different area.
As a matter of fact, I think some interest to us, you might be able to do it less expensively elsewhere than here.
Thank you very much for your submission Mr. Langston, thank you Mr. Sutton.
The case is submitted.
